column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0110] The influence of acid additives on the composition of microwaved oil is shown in FIGS. 3.4 and 3.5 and Tables 3.3 and 3.4.
#Text=Bases increase the relative concentration of sugar derivatives in the bio-oil in comparison with a control microwave experiment.
#Text=Microwave torrefaction of biomass in the presence of H.sub.2SO.sub.4 gives a narrower range of products, predominately sugar derivatives, such as L-glucosenone, in the bio-oil.

#Text=The high concentration of L-glucosenone could be explained because it is well known that acid catalysed rearrangement/dehydration of cellulose during the pyrolysis..sup.9,10 It can be seen that the yield of sugars is increased in the presence of hydrochloric acid from 29.3% to 41% in comparison with control microwave experiment.
#Text=In contrast to sulphuric acid, concentration of L-glucosenone in the oil is insignificant (1.5%).
#Text=A major component in this case is L-glucosan (35.5%).
#Text=The effect of ammonia on the composition of the oil is shown in FIG. 3.6 and Table 3.5.
#Text=L-glucosan (46%) and 2,3-dihydro-benzofurane (10.2%) are two major components of this oil. .sup.9 Nowakowski D.
#Text=J., Woodbridge C.
#Text=R., Jones J.
#Text=M., Phosphorus catalysis in the pyrolysis behaviour of biomass.
#Text=J.
#Text=Anal.
#Text=Appl.
#Text=Pyrol. 83 (2008) 197-204..sup.10 Di Blasi C., Branca C., Galgano A., Thermal and Catalytic decomposition of wood impregnated with sulfur- and phosphorus-containing ammonium salts.
#Text=Polymer Degrad.

#Text=[0111] It is significant that during the microwave-low-temperature torrefaction chem-adsorbed water, accompanied by low molecular mass acids/bases, is released separately from the organic oil (FIG. 3.8).
#Text=As a result, neither additives influence water content nor the acid number of the organic oil obtained during the microwave experiment.
#Text=In the typical low temperature microwave experiment the water content is lower than 1% of the oil mass and the acid number is lower than 10.
#Text=These parameters are much better than those for the typical fast pyrolysis oil.sup.11 and the oil obtained at the high temperature microwave pyrolysis.sup.12. .sup.11 Report 40661.
#Text=The Exploitation of Pyrolysis Oil in the Refinery Main Report.
#Text=Prepared For: The Carbon Trust.
#Text=March 2008..sup.12 Yu F., Deng S., Chen P, LIU Y., Wan Y., Olson A., Kittelson D., and Ruan R.
#Text="Physical and Chemical Properties of Bio-Oils.

column1: #Text=[0112] In a further aspect of the present invention it is demonstrated that the effects of microwave irradiation on the decomposition of each of the major constituent components: cellulose, hemi-celluloses and lignin.
